data.tiab: The Optimal Time of Ovarian Reserve Recovery After Laparoscopic Unilateral Ovarian Non-Endometriotic Cystectomy. Background Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy is established as the standard surgical approach for the treatment of benign0.55benign ovarian cysts1.0. However, previous studies have shown that potential fertility can be directly impaired by laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy, diminished0.97 ovarian reserve (DOR), and even premature ovarian failure1.0. Therefore, fertility-preserving interventions are required for benign gynecologic diseases1.0. However, there are still little data on the time period required for recovery of ovarian reserve after the laparoscopic unilateral ovarian cystectomy, which is very important for the individualization of treatment protocols. This study aimed at investigating the time needed for the ovarian reserve to recover after laparoscopic unilateral ovarian non-endometriotic cystectomy. Materials and Methods Sixty-seven patients0.98 with unilateral ovarian non-endometriotic cyst0.96 from Zhoupu and Punan Hospitals who underwent laparoscopic unilateral ovarian cystectomy were recruited as a postoperative observation group (POG). Also, 69 healthy age-matched women0.96 without ovarian cyst1.0 who did not undergo surgery were recruited as a referent group (RFG). Ovarian reserve with the serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.94 (AMH0.99), follicle-stimulating hormone1.0 (FSH1.0), estradiol1.0 (E2) levels, ovarian arterial resistance index (OARI), and antral0.47 follicle counts (AFCs) were measured on the third to fifth days of the same menstrual cycle. A postoperative 6-month follow-up of cases was performed. Results Compared with RFG, AFC of cyst side in the POG group showed no difference in the first, third, and sixth postoperative month (F = 0.03, F = 0.02, F = 0.55, respectively; p = 0.873, p = 0.878, p = 0.460, respectively). The OARI of cyst side in the POG1.0 group revealed no differences in the first, third, and sixth postoperative month (F = 0.73, F = 3.57, F = 1.75, respectively; p = 0.395, p = 0.061, p = 0.701, respectively). In the first month, the postoperative AMH0.99 levels significantly declined, reaching 1.88 ng/ml [interquartile range (IQR): 1.61-2.16 ng/ml] in POG and 2.57 ng/ml (IQR: 2.32-2.83 ng/ml) in RFG (F = 13.43, p = 0.000). For the data of AMH0.83 levels stratified by age, the same trend was observed between less than 25 and more than 26 years old. At this same time interval, the postoperative rate of decline was significantly lower compared to the preoperative one in POG (32.75%). The same trend was observed between the POG and RFG groups (26.67%). Conclusions The optimal time for recovery of ovarian reserve after laparoscopic unilateral ovarian cystectomy1.0

Methods We conducted a prospective cohort study of serum AMH0.85 concentrations in 163 non-pregnant women0.95 with CKD1.0. Serum AMH0.61 concentrations were compared with age-specific AMH0.99 centiles from 887 healthy female controls. Results Participants0.88 included 30 women0.88 with Stage 1 CKD0.8, 37 women0.89 with Stage 2 CKD, 26 women0.96 with Stage 3a CKD, 31 women0.95 with Stage 3b CKD and 39 women0.95 with Stages 4 and 5 CKD0.68. Women0.9 ages 20-24years with CKD1.0 had comparable serum AMH0.87 concentrations (median 1.959ng/mL) to women0.94 ages 35-39years without CKD1.0 (median 1.995ng/mL). data.tiab: Follicle Stimulating Hormone0.99 and Anti-Mllerian Hormone1.0 among Fertile and Infertile Women0.9 in Ile-Ife, Nigeria: Is there A Difference? BACKGROUND Reduced ovarian reserve predicts poor ovarian response and poor suc- cess rates in infertile0.99 women0.94 who undergo assisted reproductive technology (ART). Ovarian reserve also decreases with age but the rate of decline varies from one woman0.96 to another. This study aims to detect differences in ovarian reserve as measured by basal serum follicle stimulating hormone1.0 (FSH1.0) and anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.99) between a matched cohort of fertile and infertile regularly menstruating women0.92, 18-45 years of age. MATERIALS AND METHODS This case-control study involved 64 fertile and 64 subfertile0.98 women0.86 matched by age at recruitment. Peripheral blood samples were taken from the women0.93 recruited from the Gynecological and Outpatient Clinics of Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching Hospital, Ile-Ife, Nigeria. Serum FSH0.89 and AMH0.99 were quantified using ELISA at the Metabolic Research Laboratory of LAUTECH Teaching Hospital, Ogbomoso, Nigeria. RESULTS A significant difference existed in the mean FSH0.99 of fertile (6.97 3.34) and infertile (13.34 5.24, P=0.013) women0.94. We observed a significant difference in AMH between fertile (2.71 1.91) and infertile (1.60 2.51, P=0.029) women0.98. There was a negative correlation between FSH0.99 and AMH0.99 in both fertile (r=-0.311, P=0.01) and infertile (r=-0.374, P=0.002) women0.98. CONCLUSION The difference in ovarian reserve observed in this study suggests that reduced ovarian reserve in regularly menstruating women0.97 may be associated with early ovarian ageing0.82 or subfertility1.0
data.text: Longitudinal studies in fertile women have shown declines in anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) levels with age; it is the earliest marker of decline in ovarian reserve in young women.

data.tiab: Factors affecting the accuracy and reliability of the measurement of anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 concentration in the clinic. OBJECTIVE We aimed to identify the factors that influence serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.97 (AMH0.99) concentration measurements. METHODS We collected serum samples between May and September 2018 and compared the effect on AMH0.99 concentration measured by ELISA of conditions including venepuncture, storage time, storage temperature, locations of the reaction microplate, and the use of the oral contraceptive pill and gonadotrophin-releasing hormone1.0 (GnRH1.0). RESULTS AMH0.95 concentration was not affected by food intake but was affected by haemolysis. It was also much higher in samples on the edge of the ELISA microtitre plate. AMH0.99 concentration increased after incubation at room temperature for 1 day, 4C for 3 days, -20C for 1 month and -40C for 4 months, but no change occurred during storage at -80C for 9 months. AMH0.98 concentration was high in patients0.99 following GnRH0.99 agonist treatment but was not affected by oral contraceptives. CONCLUSIONS No fasting is required prior to AMH0.98 measurement. Placement of serum samples on the edge of microtitre plates affects the results of the AMH0.98 ELISA. If serum samples cannot be assayed immediately, it is best to store them at -80C. Basal AMH0.99 concentration cannot be used as a measure of ovarian reserve after GnRH0.99

data.tiab: Dietary factors and serum antimllerian hormone0.85 concentrations in late premenopausal women0.94. OBJECTIVE To study the associations between dietary factors and circulating antimllerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.99) concentrations among late premenopausal women0.93. DESIGN AMH0.98 concentrations were measured in serum samples collected at enrollment from 296 women0.96 (aged 35-45 years) in the Sister Study cohort. Usual dietary intakes in the past 12 months were assessed using a validated food frequency questionnaire. Dietary exposures of interest included macronutrients, dietary fat subtypes, fiber, and glycemic index. Multivariable linear regression was used to evaluate associations between dietary variables and serum AMH0.97 concentrations. We also used nutrient density models to examine isocaloric replacement of macronutrients. SETTING Not applicable. PATIENTS0.89 Women0.95 aged 35-45 years. INTERVENTIONS Not applicable. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Serum AMH0.84 concentrations in nanograms per milliliter (ng/mL). RESULTS AMH0.98 concentrations were positively associated with percentage of energy from carbohydrates0.98 ( per 5% calories = 0.141 [95% CI 0.023, 0.259]; P trend = .019), and inversely associated with percentage of energy from fat ( per 5% calories = -0.152 [95% CI -0.299, -0.004]; P trend = .044). In analyses of dietary fat subtypes, AMH decreased with increasing monounsaturated fatty acids1.0 (P trend = .082) and polyunsaturated fatty acids1.0 (P trend = .043), particularly -6 fatty acids (P trend = .044), whereas no strong trend was observed for saturated fatty acids1.0. Protein and alcohol0.94 intake were not strongly associated with AMH0.99. CONCLUSIONS Our cross-sectional analyses in a sample of late premenopausal women0.89 suggest that dietary fat intake may be inversely associated with circulating AMH0.99

data.tiab: Urinary phthalate1.0 metabolite concentrations are negatively associated with follicular0.51 fluid anti-mllerian hormone0.94 concentrations in women0.9 undergoing fertility0.98 treatment. Exposure to phthalates1.0, endocrine-disrupting chemicals commonly used as plasticizers and in consumer products, has been associated with infertility1.0 and premature ovarian failure1.0. Our objective was to investigate whether urinary phthalate1.0 metabolite concentrations were associated with pre-ovulatory follicular fluid (FF) anti-mllerian hormone1.0 (AMH1.0) concentrations in women0.94 undergoing fertility0.99 treatment. This cross-sectional analysis included 138 women0.98 with urinary phthalate1.0 data available in the Environment and Reproductive Health (EARTH) Study (2010-2016) in whom FF AMH0.92 concentrations were quantified using a sandwich enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). We also quantified 8 phthalate1.0 metabolite concentrations using tandem mass spectrometry in 1-2 urine samples per cycle (total 331 urines) and calculated the cycle-specific geometric mean for each metabolite. We applied cluster-weighted generalized estimating equation models (CWGEE) to evaluate the associations of tertiles of urinary phthalate1.0 metabolite concentrations with log-transformed FF AMH0.79 concentrations adjusting for potential confounders. Study participants0.98 had median age of 34.0 years (IQR 32.0, 37.0), 83% were white, and median BMI of 23.1 kg/m2 (IQR 21.2, 26.1). The following stimulation protocols were used: luteal phase agonist (70%), antagonist (14%), or flare (16%). Urinary concentrations of select phthalate1.0 metabolites were negatively associated with FF AMH. For example, women0.96 whose urinary mEOHP was in the lowest tertile (range 0.30-4.04 ng/ml) had an adjusted mean FF AMH0.65 of 0.72 ng/mL (95% CI = 0.36, 1.44), compared to women0.96 in the highest tertile (range 9.90-235), who had an adjusted mean of 0.24 ng/mL (95% CI = 0.12-0.48, p < 0.05). The negative association between urinary concentrations of certain phthalate1.0 metabolites with FF AMH0.67 concentrations may have implications for antral follicle0.61 recruitment and fertility0.96

data.tiab: Anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 concentrations in premenopausal women0.95 and breast cancer1.0 risk. Laboratory models support an inverse association between anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.99) and breast tumor0.99 development. Human0.99 studies are lacking; one study (N = 105 cases, 204 controls) with prospectively collected serum reported the opposite-an approximate 10-fold increase in breast cancer1.0 risk comparing fourth with first quartile AMH0.98 levels. We investigated the relation between serum AMH0.91 levels and breast cancer1.0 risk in a case-control (N = 452 cases, 902 controls) study nested within the prospective Sister Study cohort of 50,884 women0.93. At enrollment, participants0.96 were ages 35 to 54, premenopausal, and completed questionnaires on medical and family history, lifestyle factors, and demographics. data.tiab: Genome-Wide Association Analyses of Fertility Traits in Beef Heifers0.78. The ability of livestock to reproduce efficiently is critical to the sustainability of animal agriculture. A GWAS was performed with the AFC phenotype for 217 heifers0.9 with a multi-locus mixed model, conducted using the year, age at time of sampling and principal component analysis groupings as the covariates. The RTS GWAS was performed with 289 heifers0.94 using an additive correlation/trend test comparing prepubertal to pubertal heifers0.96. The loci on chromosomes 2, 30.56 and 23 were significant in the AFC GWAS and the loci on chromosomes 2, 8, 10 and 110.62 were significant in the RTS0.48 GWAS. The significant region on chromosome 20.9 was similar between both analyses. These regions contained genes0.52 associated with cell proliferation, transcription, apoptosis and development. This study proposes candidate genes0.51 for beef cattle0.77

data.tiab: Physiological, hyaluronan-selected intracytoplasmic sperm0.61 injection for infertility1.0 treatment (HABSelect): a parallel, two-group, randomised trial. BACKGROUND Sperm0.64 selection strategies aimed at improving success rates of intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) include binding to hyaluronic acid (herein termed hyaluronan). Hyaluronan-selected sperm0.56 have reduced levels of DNA damage and aneuploidy1.0. Use of hyaluronan-based sperm0.62 selection for ICSI (so-called physiological ICSI [PICSI]) is reported to reduce the proportion of pregnancies that end in miscarriage. However, the effect of PICSI on livebirth rates is uncertain. We aimed to investigate the efficacy of PICSI versus standard ICSI for improving livebirth rates among couples undergoing fertility0.95 treatment. METHODS This parallel, two-group, randomised trial included couples undergoing an ICSI procedure with fresh embryo transfer at 16 assisted conception units in the UK. Eligible women0.98 (aged 18-43 years) had a body-mass index of 19-35 kg/m2 and a follicle-stimulating hormone1.0 (FSH1.0) concentration of 30-200 mIU/mL or, if no FSH1.0 measurement was available, an anti-mllerian hormone1.0 concentration of at least 15 pmol/L. Couples were randomly assigned (1:1) with an online system to receive either PICSI or a standard ICSI procedure. The primary outcome was full-term (37 weeks' gestational age) livebirth, which was assessed in all eligible couples who completed follow-up. This trial is registered, number ISRCTN99214271. FINDINGS Between Feb 1, 2014, and Aug 31, 2016, 2772 couples were randomly assigned to receive PICSI (n=1387) or ICSI (n=1385), of whom 2752 (1381 in the PICSI group and 1371 in the ICSI group) were included in the primary analysis. data.tiab: Differing performance of two assays for the measurement of anti-Mullerian hormone1.0 in premenopausal women0.97: A cross-sectional study. Comparisons between the two assays were examined using Bland-Altman plots. RESULTS Participants0.96 had a mean SD age of 32.6 5.4 years and body mass index of 28.1 7.9 kg/m2 , and 60.1% were parous. data.tiab: Serum anti-mllerian hormone0.83 levels in patients0.96 with epithelial ovarian cancer1.0. Objectives. The aim of our study was to examine serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.85 (AMH0.99) concentration in ovarian cancer1.0 patients0.99 in relation to clinicopathological features, such as a pathological subtype of the tumor1.0, (FIGO) stage, grading, and overall 5-year survival. Material and Methods. We enrolled 72 epithelial ovarian cancer1.0 patients0.99 in our study, aged 45-79years, who underwent optimal cytoreductive surgery. In all patients0.99, serum AMH0.63 concentration was measured using a two-step sandwich type enzyme immunoassay before surgery. As a reference value for women0.92 over 45 years we accepted anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 concentration below 1ng/mL. Results. In the whole group of patients0.98 with ovarian cancer1.0, median serum concentration of AMH0.99 was 0.07 (0.0-0.37)ng/mL, whereas in the group of those with positive AMH0.99 values (0.14ng/mL) it was 0.31 (0.15-0.73)ng/mL. No significant correlation was found between serum AMH0.64 levels and FIGO stage, histological subtype, or grading (P > 0.05). The analysis of five-year survival rate related to AMH0.98 levels showed no statistically significant differences. There were no differences in survival rates between patients0.98 with positive or negative serum AMH0.64 levels. Conclusion. Measurement of serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.96 levels was not useful in predicting clinicopathological features and survival in patients0.93 with ovarian cancer1.0

data.tiab: Cohort profile: a prospective Australian cohort study of women0.96's reproductive PURPOSE: Previous studies have identified associations between individual reproductive factors and chronic disease1.0 risk among postmenopausal women0.93. However, few have investigated the association of different markers of reproductive function, their interactions and risk factors of chronic disease0.97 among women0.93 approaching menopause. The Menarche-to-PreMenopause (M-PreM) Study aims to examine the relationship between reproductive factors across the reproductive lifespan and risk indicators for chronic disease1.0 among women0.95 in their early-to-mid-40s. The purpose of this cohort profile paper is to describe the rationale, study design and participant0.95 characteristics of the M-PreM Study. PARTICIPANTS0.82: Women0.97 born in 1973-1978 who participated in the Australian Longitudinal Study on Women0.97's Health (ALSWH) were invited to undertake a clinical or self-administered assessment. A total of 1278women were recruited from June 2019 to June 2021. FINDINGS TO DATE: The study measures included functional, cognitive and cardiometabolic tests, anthropometry, spirometry, respiratory health questionnaires, physical activity, sleep patterns, sex hormones, and cardiovascular and metabolic markers; whereas blood and saliva samples were used for the analysis of genetic variants of genes associated with reproductive characteristics and chronic disease1.0. The mean age of the clinic and self-assessed participants0.96 was 44.6 and 45.3 years, respectively. The menopausal status of participants0.99 was similar between the two arms of the study: 38%-41%premenopausal, 20% perimenopausal, and 36% took oral contraception or hormone replacement therapy. Approximately 80% of women0.97 had at least one child and participants0.94 reported experiencing pregnancy complications: preterm birth0.99 (8%-13% of pregnancies), gestational diabetes (10%) and gestational hypertension1.0 (10%-15%). FUTURE PLANS: The biomedical data collected in the M-PreM Study will be linked to existing ALSWH survey data on sociodemographic factors, health behaviour, reproductive function, and early life factors collected over the past 20 years and health administrative data. data.tiab: Trends in anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 concentrations across different stages of pregnancy in women0.76 with polycystic ovary syndrome1.0. RESEARCH QUESTION What are the trends in anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.99) concentrations from pre-conception to the third trimester of pregnancy in women0.7 with polycystic ovary syndrome1.0 (PCOS1.0)? DESIGN Observational study including cross-sectional and longitudinal data analysis. The Beckman Coulter AMH0.95 Gen II Assay was used to determine AMH0.99 levels longitudinally before pregnancy from 52 women0.89 with PCOS1.0 and 51 controls during all trimesters. Differences in AMH0.99 levels across successive stages of pregnancy were examined with the Wilcoxon signed-rank test for paired values. Linear regression models, adjusted for body-mass index (BMI), gestational and maternal age were used to compare AMH0.99 levels of PCOS1.0 and controls. RESULTS AMH0.98 levels decreased significantly (all P < 0.05) from pre-pregnancy level throughout each trimester in women0.73 with PCOS1.0 and healthy controls. After adjusting for maternal age, gestational age and maternal BMI, AMH0.99 levels before pregnancy were 1.89 (95% CI 1.46 to 2.44; P < 0.0001) times higher among women0.8 with PCOS1.0 compared with controls (median 7.66 versus 2.67 ng/ml). During the first trimester, AMH0.99 levels were 1.61 (95% CI 1.22 to 2.13; P = 0.001) times higher among women0.78 with PCOS1.0 compared with controls (median 5.33 versus 2.48 ng/ml). Differences in AMH0.98 levels between women0.85 with PCOS1.0 and controls in the second trimester (1.68 times higher; 95% CI 0.94 to 3.01; median: 5.50 versus 2.20 ng/ml) and the third trimester (1.45 times higher; 95% CI 1.01 to 2.07; median: 1.36 versus 1.06 ng/ml) were not statistically significant. CONCLUSION These findings indicate a pregnancy-associated AMH0.98-decline independent of pre-pregnancy elevated AMH0.99

CONCLUSION This is the largest study of AMH1.0 and breast cancer1.0 risk factors among women0.91 from the general population (not presenting with infertility1.0), and it suggests that most associations are limited to women0.95

data.tiab: Depletion of ovarian reserve in young women0.83 after treatment for cancer1.0 in childhood: detection by anti-Mllerian hormone1.0, inhibin B0.98 and ovarian ultrasound. BACKGROUND Treatment of cancer1.0 during childhood may result in loss of primordial follicles0.57 from the ovary. METHODS Ten cancer1.0 survivors and 11 controls with regular menstrual cycles, in addition to 10 cancer1.0 survivors and 10 controls taking the combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP) were recruited. RESULTS Serum FSH0.59 levels were elevated in cancer1.0 survivors with regular menstrual cycles (7.5 +/- 1.4 versus 4.2 +/- 0.3 IU/l; P = 0.02), while anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.99) levels were lower (13.0 +/- 3.0 versus 21.0 +/- 3.4 pmol/l; P < 0.05). Other hormone levels were unchanged. Ovarian volume was smaller in cancer1.0 survivors than controls (3.0 +/- 0.5 versus 5.0 +/- 0.8 ml; P < 0.05), but antral0.47 follicle count (AFC) was similar. During COCP administration, inhibin B1.0 remained undetectable in six cancer1.0 survivors after FSH0.99 administration, whereas all controls showed a rise in inhibin B0.99 levels. The AFC was lower in cancer1.0 survivors than in controls (4.2 +/- 0.8 versus 7.2 +/- 0.8; P = 0.02). Ovarian volume was low in both groups, but did not differ between them. CONCLUSIONS The study results demonstrate both hormonal and biophysical evidence of partial loss of the ovarian reserve in young cancer1.0 survivors. This was detected both in women0.84 with normal menstrual cycles and during COCP0.62

data.tiab: Low ovarian reserve and risk of miscarriage1.0 in pregnancies derived from assisted STUDY QUESTION: Do low levels of anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.99) or antral0.51 follicle count (AFC) properly predict miscarriage in young women0.94 conceiving with ART? SUMMARY ANSWER: Low ovarian reserve, as indicated by AMH0.61 or AFC, is not associated with miscarriage0.84 in young women0.87 conceiving with ART. WHAT IS KNOWN ALREADY: Presently, the impact of low ovarian reserve on the risk of miscarriage remains controversial. Some studies have reported an association between serum AMH0.87 levels and AFC0.97 and miscarriage0.91, but others have failed to confirm these findings. The main limitation that undermines the reliability and consistency of the results is the confounding effect of female age. Indeed, after 35years of age, on the one hand, the risk of miscarriage0.75 starts increasing because of impaired oocyte0.66 quality while, on the other, the physiological decline in AMH0.99 and AFC0.97 levels continues, thus hampering the possibility to properly explore the real effects of reduced ovarian reserve. Indeed, the two processes, i.e. the gradual loss of resting primordial follicles and the loss of oocyte0.65 quality, progress in parallel. In other words, the older the woman0.94 becomes, the higher is the risk of miscarriage, but one cannot distinguish between the effects of biological aging on oocyte0.73 quality and those mediated by a lower ovarian reserve. STUDY DESIGN SIZE DURATION: The present retrospective monocentric cohort study was carried out at Fondazione IRCSS Ca Granda Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico, Milan. All women0.92 referred to the ART Unit between 2014 and 2021 and who underwent either conventional IVF (c-IVF), ICSI, or IUI were reviewed. Only women0.95 younger than 35 were eligible because, up to this age, the risk of miscarriage is steady and not strictly related to age. PARTICIPANTS0.92/MATERIALS SETTING METHODS: Women0.92 younger than 35 who achieved a singleton clinical pregnancy with c-IVF, ICSI, or IUI were selected. Women0.86 with patent causes of recurrent miscarriage0.99 were excluded, as well as those undergoing pregnancy termination for fetal or medical causes. Women0.93 who did and did not have a pregnancy loss before 20 weeks' gestation were compared. Detailed information was obtained from charts of the consulting patients0.99. ART procedures were performed according to the standardized policy of our Unit. All women0.88 underwent serum AMH0.93 measurement and a transvaginal assessment of AFC prior to initiation of treatment. AMH0.99 levels were measured by a commercially available ELISA assay. To assess AFC, all identifiable antral follicles0.75 2-10mm in diameter at ultrasound were recorded. The primary outcome was the risk of miscarriage for women0.93 with serum AMH0.92 levels below 5pmol/l. MAIN RESULTS AND THE ROLE OF CHANCE: There were 538 women0.94 were included, of whom 92 (17%) had a miscarriage. The areas under the ROC curves for prediction of miscarriage based on AMH0.99 levels and AFC were 0.51 (95% CI: 0.45-0.58) and 0.52 (95% CI: 0.45-0.59), respectively. The odds ratio (OR) of miscarriage for women0.95 with serum AMH0.98 levels below 5.0pmol/l was 1.10 (95% CI: 0.51-2.36); the adjusted OR was 1.12 (95% CI: 0.51-2.45). Analyses were repeated considering other thresholds for AMH0.57 (2.9, 3.6 and 7.9pmol/l) and for AFC (thresholds of 7 and 10). No associations emerged. LIMITATIONS REASONS FOR CAUTION: The retrospective design of the study hampered the collection of more precise but potentially relevant clinical information of the couples. We did not exclude women0.91 suffering from PCOS1.0, a condition possibly associated with miscarriage. Moreover, the baseline characteristics of women0.93 who did and did not have a miscarriage differed in some characteristics. Thus, we adjusted the OR using a multivariate analysis, but we cannot fully exclude residual confounding effects. Finally, our results cannot be inferred to women0.96 older than 35. The mechanisms causing premature exhaustion of ovarian reserve may be different in younger and older women0.92 and this may lead to a different impact on the risk of miscarriage. WIDER IMPLICATIONS OF THE FINDINGS: Women0.86

data.tiab: The Future of Breast Cancer1.0 Research in the Survivorship Field. Prevalence of survivors of breast cancer1.0 has been steadily increasing in the last 20 years. Currently, more than 90% of women0.94 diagnosed with early-stage0.98 breast cancer0.97 are expected to be alive at 5 years from diagnosis thanks to early detection and breakthrough innovations in multimodal treatment strategies. Alongside this advancement in clinical outcomes, survivors of breast cancer1.0 might experience several specific challenges and present with unique needs. Survivorship trajectories after diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer1.0 can be significantly impacted by long-lasting and severe treatment-related side effects, including physical problems, psychological distress, fertility issues in young women0.77, and impaired social and work reintegration, which add up to patients0.98' individual risk of cancer1.0 recurrence and second primary malignancies0.85. Alongside cancer1.0-specific sequelae, survivors still present with general health needs, including management of chronic preexisting or ensuing conditions. Survivorship care should implement high-quality, evidence-based strategies to promptly screen, identify, and address survivors' needs in a comprehensive way and minimize the impact of severe treatment sequelae, preexisting comorbidities, unhealthy lifestyles, and risk of recurrence on quality of life. This narrative review focuses on core areas of survivorship care and discuss the state of the art and future research perspectives in key domains including selected long-term side effects, surveillance for recurrences and second cancers0.99

data.tiab: Assessment of Circulating Anti-Mllerian Hormone1.0 in Women0.92 Using Hormonal Contraception: A Systematic Review. The status of ovarian0.48 reserve markers during hormonal contraception (HC) remains uncertain with conflicting literature data. The purpose of this study was to assess the impact of HC on circulating anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.98) and other ovarian reserve markers. A systematic review was conducted, including all cohort, cross-sectional, and randomized controlled studies assessing serum anti Mllerian hormone0.81 concentration in women0.9 using HC. Data sources included MEDLINE, EMBASE, DynaMed Plus, ScienceDirect, TRIP database, ClinicalTrials.gov, and the Cochrane Library from January 2000 to October 2018. A total of 366 studies were identified, of which 15 were eligible, including 3280 women0.96, mostly using combined HC (CHC). Articles were divided according to duration of HC into short- (2-3 weeks), medium- (2-6 months), long- (>1 year), and varied-term studies. Two study designs were identified, including studies comparing AMH before and during/after CHC and studies comparing CHC users versus nonusers. Short- and medium-term studies (n=284) reported no change in circulating AMH0.99 in women0.86 using cyclical CHC for one to six cycles. Apart from one study, all long- and varied-term studies (six studies, n=1601) consistently showed a marked decline in AMH, antral follicle0.49 count, and ovarian volume. Three long-term studies (n=1324) provided evidence of AMH0.99 recovery after discontinuation of HC. Circulating AMH0.99 seems to remain unchanged in women0.82

data.tiab: Plasma Anti-Mllerian Hormone Concentrations and Risk of Breast Cancer1.0 among Premenopausal Women0.87 in the Nurses0.58' Health Studies. BACKGROUND Anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.98) is a member of the TGF family0.99 of growth and differentiation factors with a key role in regulating folliculogenesis. In experimental studies, using supraphysiologic concentrations, AMH0.99 inhibits breast cancer1.0 growth. However, high levels of AMH0.94 were associated with increased breast cancer0.99 risk in two prior prospective epidemiologic studies. METHODS We conducted a nested case-control study of premenopausal plasma AMH and breast cancer1.0 risk within the Nurses0.71' Health Study (NHS) and NHSII. In NHS, 32,826 women0.97 donated blood samples in 1989-1990; in NHSII, 29,611 women0.97 donated samples in 1996-1999. After blood collection and before February 2004 (NHS) or July 2010 (NHSII), 539 cases were diagnosed among women0.91 premenopausal at diagnosis, and were matched 1:1 to controls. ORs and 95% confidence intervals (CI) were calculated using unconditional logistic regression, adjusting for matching and breast cancer1.0 risk factors. RESULTS Higher plasma levels of AMH were associated with increased breast cancer0.99 risk (top vs. bottom quintile multivariate OR, 2.20; 95% CI, 1.34-3.63; P trend = 0.001). The association did not vary by invasive versus in situ disease or by estrogen1.0estrogen receptor0.99 status. Associations were not significantly different by age at blood or diagnosis. Further adjustment for plasma estradiol1.0 or testosterone0.99 yielded similar results. CONCLUSIONS Higher circulating AMH0.98 levels are associated with increased breast cancer0.99 risk among premenopausal women0.91. IMPACT The significant positive association between premenopausal plasma AMH0.63 levels and subsequent breast cancer1.0 risk before menopause suggests AMH1.0 may be useful as a marker of breast cancer1.0 risk in younger women0.9

data.tiab: Anti-Mllerian Hormone0.99 Concentrations Are Inversely Associated With Subclinical Atherosclerosis in Premenopausal Women0.92. Anti-Mllerian hormone0.99 (AMH0.98), which is secreted by granulosa cells0.82 of late preantral and small antral follicles, is a marker of ovarian reserve. The association of ovarian reserve with subclinical atherosclerosis1.0 in women0.83 of reproductive age is currently unknown. We primary investigated whether AMH0.99 levels are associated with markers of subclinical atherosclerosis0.94 in healthy, normally menstruating women0.9. In this cross-sectional study, vascular structure and function were assessed by measurement of carotid and femoral intima-media thickness (IMT), flow-mediated dilation, carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity and augmentation index. Lipid profile and serum AMH0.92 concentrations were also measured. Seventy premenopausal women0.97, aged 32.7 6.5 years, were included. Mean AMH0.99 levels were lower in smokers than in non-smokers and negatively associated with total cholesterol0.99 (TC) levels. An inverse association between mean AMH0.99 concentrations and femoral and carotid IMT in all segments was observed. No correlation with other markers of subclinical atherosclerosis1.0 or established cardiovascular (CV) risk factors was found. After multivariable adjustment, the association between AMH0.98 concentrations and combined carotid IMT or carotid bulb IMT remained significant. In conclusion, in healthy, normally ovulating women0.87, AMH0.99 concentrations are negatively associated with subclinical atherosclerosis0.99

data.tiab: Fecundity disorders1.0 in older women0.9: declines in follicular development and endometrial receptivity. BACKGROUND Little research is available on follicular development and endometrial receptivity in older women0.88. This study aimed to assess follicular development and endometrial receptivity, and to evaluate ultrasonic parameters in predicting endometrial receptivity during the implantation window in older women0.81. METHODS For this prospective case-control study, 224 older women0.93 and 215 young women0.94 were recruited. The follicular development and endometrial thickness were monitored by transvaginal ultrasound. During the implantation window, the pulsatility index (PI) and resistance index (RI) of the uterine0.44 arteries and subendometrial region, endometrial volume, vascularization index (VI), flow index (FI) and vascularization flow index (VFI) were calculated between the two groups. The ultrasonic parameters were used to assess endometrial receptivity in older women0.88. RESULTS The serum anti-Mullerian hormone0.98 (AMH0.99) concentration and antral0.48 follicle count (AFC) were significantly lower in older women0.97 than in young women0.97. The average diameter of the dominant follicle on days 14, 16, and 18 of the menstrual cycle were significantly smaller, and the subendometrial region RI on days 12, 14, 16, and 18 of the menstrual cycle were significantly higher in older women0.97 than in young women0.96. The normal ovulation rate was significantly lower in older women0.97 than in young women0.96. The subendometrial region RI was significantly higher, and the endometrial VI, FI, and VFI were significantly lower in older women0.96 compared with young women0.94. The biochemical pregnancy rate, clinical pregnancy rate and ongoing pregnancy rate of older women0.97 were significantly lower than in young women0.96. The best ultrasonic parameter for predicting endometrial receptivity during the implantation window in older women0.86 was VI (AUC =0.889, sensitivity 92.6% and specificity 85.4%). CONCLUSIONS Older women0.92 present decreased serum AMH0.95 concentrations and AFC, defined as indicators of ovarian reserve function. Older women0.95 are characterized by decreased follicular development and endometrial receptivity, which may lead to fecundity disorders0.87

data.tiab: Connection between Celiac Disease1.0 and Systemic Lupus Erythematosus1.0 in Children0.97-A Celiac disease1.0 (CD1.0) and systemic lupus erythematosus1.0 (SLE1.0) are two diseases intensively studied in all age groups, with an increasing incidence at the global level, possibly due to the increased awareness of the diseases and their accurate diagnosis and as a consequence of the new research and innovation technologies that have appeared in medicine. The first is a controllable condition found in approximately 1% of the entire population in the form of a reaction to environmental stimuli affecting individuals with genetic susceptibility, causing gluten intolerance1.0, gastrointestinal and extradigestive symptoms1.0, starting from subclinical stages and culminating in severe malabsorption1.0. On the other hand, lupus1.0 is an autoimmune disease1.0 with chameleon-like symptoms and found mainly in the female sex, which leaves its clinical mark on most organs, from the skin, eyes, and kidneys to the cardiovascular, pulmonary, neurological, osteoarticular, and hematological systems. Current studies focus on the correlation between celiac disease1.0 and other autoimmune pathologies1.0 such as autoimmune thyroiditis1.0 (Hashimoto0.98 and Graves-Basedow0.84), type I diabetes1.0, and systemic lupus erythematosus1.0. The current review aims to present a summary of the data from the specialized literature regarding the intercurrents between celiac disease1.0 and lupus1.0

METHODS A comprehensive literature search was conducted in PubMed, Cochrane and Scopus, through to December 6th, 2020. RESULTS Four prospective studies were included in the qualitative and quantitative analysis. data.tiab: Addressing ethical issues related to prenatal diagnostic procedures. BACKGROUND: For women0.9 of advanced maternal age or couples with high risk of genetic mutations, the ability to screen for embryos0.47 free of certain genetic0.66 mutations is reassuring, as it provides opportunity to address age-related decline in fertility through preimplantation genetic testing. This procedure has potential to facilitate better embryo selection, improve implantation rates with single embryo transfer and reduce miscarriage rates, among others, yet confers some risk to the embryo and additional costs of assisted reproductive technology. This raises questions whether, when and which patients0.98 should receive routine PGT-A prior to embryo transfer. DISCUSSION: Prenatal diagnostic procedures refer to tests done when one or both genetic parents has a known genetic disorder1.0 (or has worries about the disorder) and testing is performed on them, their gametes0.69 or on the embryos0.53 to determine if the latter is likely to carry a genetic disorder1.0. PGT is used to identify genetic defects1.0 in gametes0.79 or embryos0.69 (often created through in vitro fertilization (IVF). The procedures generate immense potential to improve health and wellbeing by preventing conception or birth of babies with undesirable traits, life-limiting conditions and even lethal conditions. However, they generate a lot of information, which often may challenge decision-making ability of healthcare providers and parents, and raise ethical challenges. CONCLUSION: Prenatal diagnostic procedures have potential to address uncertainty and risk of having a child0.64 affected with a genetic disease1.0. They, however, often raise own uncertainty and controversies, whose origin, manifestation and related ethical issues are presented. data.tiab: Clinical review: Adolescent anovulation1.0: maturational mechanisms and implications. CONTEXT Adolescents are at high risk for menstrual dysfunction1.0. The diagnosis of anovulatory disorders1.0 that may have long-term health consequences is too often delayed. EVIDENCE ACQUISITION A review of the literature in English was conducted, and data were summarized and integrated from the author's perspective. MAIN FINDINGS Normal adolescent anovulation0.72 causes only minor menstrual cycle irregularity: most cycles range from 21-45 days, even in the first postmenarcheal year, 90% by the fourth year. Approximately half of symptomatic menstrual irregularity1.0 is due to neuroendocrine immaturity1.0, and half is associated with increased androgen1.0 levels. The former is manifest as aluteal or short/deficient luteal phase cycles and usually resolves spontaneously. The latter seems related to polycystic ovary syndrome1.0 because adolescent androgen1.0 levels are associated with adult androgens1.0 and ovulatory dysfunction1.0, but data are sparse. Obesity1.0 causes hyperandrogenemia1.0 and, via unclear mechanisms, seems to suppress LHnan; it may mimic polycystic ovary syndrome1.0. The role of pubertal insulin1.0 resistance in physiological adolescent anovulation is unclear. High-sensitivity gonadotropin1.0 and steroid0.99 assays, the latter by specialty laboratories, are necessary for accurate diagnosis of pubertal disorders1.0. Polycystic ovaries1.0 are a normal ultrasonographic finding in young women0.83 and are associated with nearly 2-fold increased anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 levels. Oral contraceptives are generally the first-line treatment for ongoing menstrual dysfunction1.0, and the effects of treatment are similar among preparations. CONCLUSIONS Menstrual cycle duration persistently outside 21-45 days in adolescents is unusual, and persistence 1 year suggests that disordered hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal function be considered. Research is needed on the mechanisms and prognosis of adolescent anovulation0.78

This study investigated DHEAS ability to predict live birth before starting the first gonadotrophin-releasing hormone1.0 (GnRH1.0) antagonist ovarian stimulation for IVF/intracytoplasmic sperm injection in young women0.95 (37years) with low serum AMH0.88 (<6.5pmol/l). Medical records of 90patients were analysed. DHEAS was predictive for live birth (AUC-ROC 0.69, 95% CI 0.59-0.79). Its predictive accuracy for live birth was similar to that of the number of oocytes0.74 retrieved. The cut-off value for DHEAS of 5.4mol/l offered the best discriminative performance between patients0.98 who achieved live birth and those who did not. The live birth rate per initiated cycle in women0.93 with DHEAS concentration >5.4mol/l was 5-fold higher compared with women0.93 with DHEAS 5.4mol/l (38.9% versus 7.4%, P<0.001) despite similar oocyte0.65 yield in both groups. In conclusion, the association between baseline DHEAS and probability of live birth after the GnRH0.99 antagonist IVF cycle in young women0.87 with low AMH0.56 was demonstrated. This association could not be explained by the effect of DHEAS on the oocyte0.62 yield. This study demonstrates an association of baseline dehydroepinadrostendione sulphate1.0 (DHEAS1.0) concentration with implantation rate and live birth rate after the first gonadotrophin-releasing hormone1.0 antagonist IVF cycle in young women0.86 who are expected to respond poorly to ovarian stimulation. Compared with the number of oocytes0.71 retrieved, DHEAS showed a similar ability to distinguish women0.93 who will achieve a live birth from those who will not. However, as a parameter available to clinicians and patients0.98 before commencing an ovarian stimulation for IVF, DHEAS could be used in predicting probability of live birth at the initial consultation. Women0.95 whose DHEAS concentrations were above the derived cut-off value 5.4mol/l had 5-fold more favourable prognosis for live birth than their counterparts with DHEAS concentrations below the cut-off value. The findings could not be explained by the difference in the oocyte0.57 yield and/or the number of embryos transferred but rather by the possible association between the endogenous DHEAS0.97 concentration and the oocyte0.62

data.tiab: Circular RNA0.73 expression profiling of human granulosa cells0.88human0.97 granulosa cells during maternal aging reveals novel transcripts associated with assisted reproductive technology outcomes. Our study aimed to investigate circRNA0.76 profiles in human granulosa cells0.81human0.92 granulosa cells (GCs0.83) during maternal aging and to uncover age-related circRNA0.78 variations that potentially reflect decreased oocyte0.58 competence. The correlation between circRNAs0.64 expression and clinical characteristics was analyzed in additional 80 samples. Chip-based analysis revealed 46 up-regulated and 11 down-regulated circRNAs0.54 in AAnan samples (fold change > 2.0). Specifically, circRNA_1038290.83, circRNA_1038270.8 and circRNA_1048160.75 were validated to be up-regulated, while circRNA_1018890.7 was down-regulated in AAnan samples. After adjustment for gonadotropin0.97 treatment, only circRNA_1038270.88 and circRNA_0.5circRNA_1048160.86 levels were positively associated with maternal age (partial r = 0.332, P = 0.045; partial r = 0.473, P = 0.003; respectively). Moreover, circRNA_1038270.92 and circRNA_1048160.91 expressions in GCs0.77 were negatively correlated with the number of top quality embryos (r = -0.235, P = 0.036; r = -0.221, P = 0.049; respectively). Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis indicated that the performance of circRNA_1038270.93 for live birth prediction reached 0.698 [0.570-0.825], with 77.2% sensitivity and 60.9% specificity (P = 0.006), and that of circRNA_1048160.91 was 0.645 [0.507-0.783] (P = 0.043). data.tiab: Acute Supplementation with High Dose Vitamin D31.0 Increases Serum Anti-Mllerian Hormone0.88 in Young Women0.91. Vitamin D1.0 (Vit D1.0) regulates AMH0.99 production in vitro, but its role as a regulator of ovarian AMH0.57 production is contentious. If Vit D1.0 influences ovarian AMH production, then an acute rise in Vit D1.0 level should lead to an acute rise in circulating AMH0.97 levels. This hypothesis was tested with a randomized double-blind design, with 18-25-year-old women0.88 recruited from the community. The study was conducted in early spring, when the marker of Vit D1.0 level (25-hydroxyvitamin D1.0, 25(OH)D1.0) tends to be at its nadir. The women0.92 consumed either an oral dose of 50,000 IU of Vit D31.0 (n = 27) or placebo (n = 22). The initial 25(OH)D1.0 SD value was 53.6 23.3 nmol/L, with 42 of the 49 women0.98 having a value below 75 nmol/L, consistent with seasonal nadir. All women0.94 receiving Vit D31.0 treatment exhibited a robust increase in serum 25(OH)D1.0 within 1 day (15.8 1.1 nmol/L (n = 27), p < 0.0001), with the increase sustained over the study week. Circulating levels of AMH0.98 in the women0.93 receiving Vit D31.0 progressively rose during the following week, with a mean increase of 12.9 3.7% (n = 24, p = 0.001). The study supports the hypothesis that Vit D1.0's positive effects on the fertility of woman0.67 may involve the regulation of ovarian AMH0.91

data.tiab: Age-specific random day serum antimllerian hormone0.78 reference values for women0.77 of BACKGROUND: Antimllerian hormone0.98, the most reliable biomarker of ovarian reserve, is widely used in various clinical situations. Antimllerian hormone0.99 levels consistently decrease with age. However, there is no standard, age-specific reference values for antimllerian hormone in women0.89 of reproductive age, which limits its application. OBJECTIVE: This study aimed to establish age-specific antimllerian hormone0.99 percentile reference values for women0.89 of reproductive age. A total of 10,053 eligible women0.96 aged 20 to 49 years were selected using a multistage stratified sampling procedure. Women0.92 who were pregnant, had undergone ovarian surgery, took hormone drugs in the past 3 months, or had an antimllerian hormone outlier value were excluded from establishing antimllerian hormone0.93 percentile reference values. Serum antimllerian hormone0.95 concentrations were measured using ultrasensitive, 2-site enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (Ansh Lab, Webster, TX) in the Reproductive Endocrinology Laboratory of Peking University Third Hospital. Generalized additive models for location scale and shape with the Box-Cox t original distribution were used to estimate the fitted antimllerian hormone0.99 percentile reference values. RESULTS: A total of 9112 eligible women0.96 aged 21 to 49 years were included in the fitting model. The fitted 50th (2.5th-97.5th) percentiles of antimllerian hormone0.96 values for women0.94 aged 21, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, and 49 years were 4.83 (0.79-18.41), 4.47 (0.72-16.58), 3.67 (0.50-13.82), 2.59 (0.24-10.35), 1.35 (0.05-6.68), 0.33 (<0.01 to 3.40), and 0.04 (<0.01 to 1.77) ng/mL, respectively. The population-based decline rate of antimllerian hormone accelerated with increasing age, especially age >35 years. The magnitude of the decline of the 25th antimllerian hormone0.98 percentile curve was greater than that of the 75th percentile curve. AIM The aim was to assess the influence of dietary counselling on the pubertal development and hormonal status in healthy adolescents. METHODS We used a subcohort of 193 healthy boys0.95 (52%) and girls0.96 (48%) from the Special Turku Coronary Risk Factor Intervention Project. Participants0.93 were recruited by nurses0.48 at the well-baby clinics in Turku Finland in 1990-1992 and randomised into intervention and control groups. Intervention children0.96 received low-saturated fat and low-cholesterol0.99 dietary counselling initiated at seven months of age. Participants0.87 were examined once a year with Tanner staging, anthropometric measurements and serial reproductive hormones from 10 to 19 years of age. In girls0.61, postmenarcheal hormones were not analysed. RESULTS Pubertal hormones in boys0.91 or girls0.91 did not differ between the intervention and control groups. However, we observed slight differences in pubertal progression by Tanner staging and in anthropometric parameters. The intervention boys0.93 progressed faster to G4 (p = 0.008), G5 (p = 0.008) and P5 (p = 0.03). The intervention boys0.96 were taller than control boys0.97

data.tiab: Limitations in use of ovarian reserve biomarkers to predict the superovulation High FSH1.0 doses during superovulation of heifers0.98 with a small ovarian reserve increase the number of dysfunctional ovulatory-size follicles that do not ovulate in response to human chorionic gonadotropin0.99human0.87 chorionic gonadotropin (hCG1.0). Thus, anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 (AMH1.0) and antral0.57 follicle count (AFC), two well-established biomarkers of responsiveness of individuals to superovulation, are hypothesized to be positively linked to number of dysfunctional ovulatory-size follicles0.5 developing in response to superovulation with high FSH1.0 doses. To test this hypothesis, heifers0.95 with a small ovarian reserve were stimulated beginning on Day 1 of the estrous cycle with twice daily treatments for 4 days with each of four Folltropin-V0.96 (FSH1.0) doses (35 IU, 70 IU (industry standard), 140 IU, or 210 IU) followed by prostaglandin0.96 F(2) to regress corpora lutea0.89 (CL) from the previous estrous cycle and hCG0.99 to induce ovulation. Ovulatory-size follicles0.57 were classified as functional or dysfunctional based on whether they ovulated and formed CL in response to hCG0.99. FSH0.99 dose did not impact the relationship between AMH0.99, AFC and the number of functional or dysfunctional ovulatory-size follicles0.59 developing in response to superovulation. Thus, data from the four superovulations were averaged for each heifer0.93. AMH0.98 and AFC0.51 were positively associated with the subsequent number of functional and dysfunctional ovulatory-size follicles0.48 and the proportion of ovulatory-size follicles that are dysfunctional after superovulation. Because measurements of AMH0.99 concentration and AFC predict the number but not functionality of ovulatory-size follicles, which may also impact oocyte0.75 quality, these ovarian reserve biomarkers are concluded to be unlikely useful to improve IVF or embryo transfer outcomes in heifers0.93

data.tiab: Serum AMH0.95 concentration as a marker evaluating gonadal function in boys0.83 operated on for unilateral cryptorchidism1.0 between 1st and 4th year of life. The aim of this study was to measure the serum AMH0.92 (anti-Mullerian hormone1.0) concentrations in a group of boys0.9 with or without cryptorchidism1.0, evaluation of karyotypes, testicular position, morphology, and major length of the undescended testes. Fifty boys0.94 who were 1-4 years old (median = 2.4 years) with unilateral cryptorchidism0.96 were evaluated. All of them underwent orchidopexy in 2010. Prior to the procedure, all of the subjects had undergone karyotyping to exclude chromosomal abnormalities1.0. Fifty healthy boys0.94 within the same age range (median = 2.1 years) admitted for planned inguinal hernia1.0 repair in 2010, served as controls. Blood samples were collected, while obtaining blood for standard laboratory tests routinely performed before the surgeries. Medians of AMH in boys0.95 with cryptorchidism1.0 were lower than in boys0.94 with inguinal hernia1.0 and differed significantly between two groups. Undescended testes0.92 were generally found in superficial inguinal pouch (n = 46), in two cases were noted to be in the external ring of the inguinal canal, and in another two instances, in the abdominal cavity. The major lengths of the undescended testes were smaller in comparison to the testes positioned normally (mean of 1 cm vs. a mean of 1.5 cm, respectively). In nine of the cases, the testes had turgor deficit0.81, a drop shape, with epididymides that were small, dysplastic, and separated from the testis. The authors found that AMH0.98 was lower in boys0.93 with unilateral cryptorchidism1.0

data.tiab: [Ovarian function in young women0.84 after anticancer treatment in childhood]. AIM We investigated pituitary-ovarian function in young women0.82 after treatment for different cancers1.0 in prepubertal and pubertal periods, with or without radiotherapy of infradiaphragmatic areas. PATIENTS0.98 AND METHODS We analyzed the values of follicle-stimulating hormone1.0 (FSH1.0) luteinizing hormone1.0 (LH1.0), estradiol1.0 (E2), inhibin B0.99 and anti-mllerian hormone (AMH0.99) in the group of 28 young women0.86 aged 18.6 +/- 4.7 years, who had been treated for Hodgkin's Lymphoma1.0 HLnan (n=16), nephroblastoma1.0 (n=7), soft tissue sarcoma1.0 (n=4), neuroblastoma1.0 (n=1). Abdominal irradiation was given in fifteen survivors. Control group was composed of ten healthy women0.95 at similar age. RESULTS In the whole group the mean levels of FSH1.0, LHnan and E2 did not differ from the control group, but in the subgroup irradiated infradiaphragmatically FSH0.94 concentration was higher than in the control group (8.06+/-3.28 vs 5.8+/-2.03 mIU/ml) p=0.042, particularly after HL treatment (8.53+/-3.25 mIU/ml), p=0.045. Mean AMH0.99 levels were significantly lower in the whole analyzed group than in the control one (22.8+/-16.3 vs 29.4+/-13.2 pmol/l) p=0.036, particularly in the subgroup irradiated for abdomen (17.2+/-14.9 pmol/l) p=0.025. Inhibin B0.99 was also lower in the whole group, (27.98+/-17.8 ng/l vs 47.9+/-26.4 ng/l) p=0.035, and in the subgroup with non-irradiated abdomen 25.9+/-14.1 ng/l, p=0.01. We did not observe the influence of age at treatment (prepubertal vs pubertal period) on the values of analyzed hormones. We found a correlation between AMH0.99 and inhibin B0.99. CONCLUSIONS In young women0.87 after anti0.91-cancer treatment, with normal menstrual cycles, the signs of ovarian dysfunction1.0 and diminished ovarian reserve are observed. This situation can lead to a shorter period of fertility. Those women0.95

data.tiab: Retinol1.0Retinol-binding protein 41.0 (RBP41.0) and high sensitivity C-reactive protein0.97 (hs-CRP1.0) levels in patients0.97 with diminished ovarian reserve1.0 (DOR1.0): a cross-sectional study. BACKGROUND Antioxidant/oxidant imbalance has been reported to be related to diminished0.96 ovarian reserve (DOR0.75). Vitamin A1.0 (retinol1.0), a kind of antioxidant, plays a role in restoring ovarian oxidative damage, while C-reactive protein1.0 (CRP1.0) is the classical marker of oxidative stress and has recently been identified as an independent variable that is associated with low anti-Mullerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.99) levels in young women0.93 with DOR. Additionally, retinol1.0retinol binding protein 41.0 (RBP41.0) can be considered a substitute for retinol1.0 in healthy, nonobese women0.91. The study aim was to determine the relationship between serum0.71 RBP40.67, high sensitivity C-reactive protein0.99 (hs-CRP1.0) concentrations and ovarian reserve in nonobese DOR1.0 patients0.99. METHODS This study included 24 DOR1.0 women0.98 and 48 normal ovarian reserve (NOR) women0.97 from the reproductive medical center of Renmin Hospital of Wuhan University. The serum RBP40.96 and high-sensitivity CRP0.99 (hs-CRP0.99) levels were measured with ELISA kits. RESULTS RBP41.0 levels (20,648.365475.16ng/ml vs 23,986.485995.64ng/ml, p=0.025) were decreased, and hs-CRP0.99 levels (695.081090.19ng/ml vs 364.32786.29ng/ml, p=0.012) were increased in the DOR0.62 group. Serum RBP40.65 was positively related to AMH0.66 (Pearson r=0.518, p=0.000), while hs-CRP0.99 was negatively correlated with AMH (Spearman r=-0.345, p=0.005). after adjustments were made for the covariables, multiple line regression analysis showed that positive association between RBP41.0 and AMH0.9 still existed (=0.450, p < 0.001). CONCLUSION Decreased serum RBP40.79 levels and increased serum hs-CRP1.0 were observed in DOR0.57 patients0.99 in our study, and the strong correlation between RBP40.99 and AMH0.64 supports the notion that oxidative stress plays a role in DOR1.0, and that appropriate levels of antioxidant vitamin A1.0 may be protective against ovarian reserve dysfunction1.0

data.tiab: Effect of obesity1.0 and its related metabolic factors on serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.88 concentrations in women0.86 with and without polycystic ovaries1.0. The relationship between serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.88 (AMH0.99) levels, body mass index (BMI) and related metabolic factors were investigated in women0.66 with polycystic ovary syndrome1.0 (PCOS1.0). A total of 691 women0.96 aged between 18 and 35 years, referred to the Department of Gynaecological Endocrinology at the University Hospital of Lille between 2009 and 2014 were included: 137 controls and 554 women0.91 with PCOS1.0. Mean serum AMH0.99 levels were slightly but significantly lower in women0.9 with PCOS1.0 who were overweight or obese0.65 (BMI 25) compared with women0.94 of normal weight (BMI <25) (P < 0.05). No such difference was found in the control group. After bivariate analysis, no significant correlation was found between BMI and AMH0.7 in controls. In the PCOS1.0 group, this relationship was significant (P = 0.0001) but weak (r = -0.177). Stepwise multiple regression analysis yielded a significant model, including five variables (follicle0.68 count, serum androstenedione1.0, BMI, serum LH0.98 and FSH1.0) explaining 38.6%, 3.4%, 1.4%, 0.7% and 1.4% of the total serum AMH0.95 variance, respectively. No effect of metabolic status was found on serum AMH0.91 levels in controls, but a significant, albeit weak, negative independent correlation was found between AMH0.99 and BMI in women0.7 with PCOS1.0

data.tiab: Anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 concentrations and parity in fertile1.0 women0.9: the model of oocyte0.71 donors. In France until the end of 2015, oocyte0.66 donors must have had at least one child0.64 and be aged 18-37 years. This population of fertile women0.91 was selected to examine whether serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.95 (AMH0.99) concentration could be a reliable correlate of spontaneous pregnancy in women0.9 who had proven their fertility before. A cohort of 217 women0.97 followed between 2009 and 2015 for oocyte0.66 donation at the University Hospital of Lille comprised this retrospective study. In these egg0.46 donors, aged 20-37 (median: 32 years), the median serum AMH0.99 level was 22pmol/l (5-95th percentiles: 4.9-61.8). No significant correlation was found between serum AMH0.93 level and the number of children0.97 or the youngest child0.91's age. Among the 32 women0.97 with AMH0.97 <10pmol/l, 9 and 3 were less than 30 and 25 years old, respectively. Six women0.98 (2.8%) had undetectable serum AMH0.68, i.e. <3pmol/l. In conclusion, serum AMH0.97 level measured in this fertile female cohort showed too much variability to be a good fertility index. Assessment of serum AMH0.97 should only be discussed for patients0.98 at risk of ovarian failure1.0

data.tiab: Clinical outcomes for Day 3 double cleavage-stage embryo transfers versus Day 5 OBJECTIVE: This study aimed to compare the clinical outcomes for transfer of Day 3 (D3) double cleavage-stage embryos and Day 5/6 (D5/6) single blastocysts0.52 in the frozen embryo transfer (FET) cycle to formulate a more appropriate embryo transplantation strategy. METHODS: We retrospectively analyzed 609 FET cycles from 518 women0.96 from April 2017 to March 2021. All FETs0.92 were assigned to the D3-DET group (transfer of a Day 3 double cleavage-stage embryo), D5-SBT group (transfer of a Day 5 single blastocyst), or D6-SBT group (transfer of a Day 6 single blastocyst). Clinical outcomes were comparatively analyzed. RESULTS: There were no significant differences in the biochemical pregnancy rate, clinical pregnancy rate, or ongoing pregnancy rate between the D3-DET and D5-SBT groups, but these rates in the two groups were all significantly higher compared with those in the D6-SBT group. The implantation rate in the D5-SBT0.85 group was significantly higher than that in the D3-DET0.99 group. The twin pregnancy rate in the D5-SBT and D6-SBT groups was significantly lower than that in the D3-DET0.89
data.text: There were no significant differences in age, body mass index (BMI), length of infertility, anti-Mullerian hormone concentrations, ovarian stimulation protocol (antagonist or agonist), average number of oocytes retrieved, fertilization method (intracytoplasmic sperm injection or IVF), or endometrial thickness at the embryo transfer among the three groups (Table 1).

data.tiab: Anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 and vascular dysfunction1.0 in women0.84 with chronic kidney1.0 Young women0.92 with chronic kidney disease1.0 (CKD1.0) have disproportionately increased risk of cardiovascular mortality. Reduced anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.99) is linked to poor cardiovascular outcomes in the general population, but whether AMH1.0 is associated with increased cardiovascular risk in the high-risk CKD1.0 population is unknown. This study examined the association between AMH0.88 and vascular function, validated markers of cardiovascular risk, in women0.71 with CKD1.0. An exploratory cross-sectional study was performed in 47 young women0.88 with CKD1.0. Laboratory measurements of AMH were collected. Using standardized protocols, endothelial function was measured with brachial artery flow-mediated dilation and hyperemic velocity time integral. Arterial stiffness was measured with aortic augmentation index and pulse wave velocity. Multivariate linear regression analyses were utilized to evaluate the association between AMH0.99 levels and each measure of vascular health. Forty women0.98 (36 7 years) with non-dialysis-dependent CKD and 7 women0.96 (38 6 years) with dialysis-dependent CKD1.0 participated. AMH0.98 levels were inversely associated with age (p = 0.01) but not associated with eGFR (p = 0.59) or dialysis status (p = 0.97). AMH1.0 was associated with brachial artery flow-mediated dilation (R(2) = 0.21 [p = 0.03]) and aortic augmentation index (R(2) = 0.20 [p = 0.04]) in the non-dialysis-dependent participants0.95, and with aortic augmentation0.47 index in all participants0.97 (R(2) = 0.18 [p = 0.03]). data.tiab: Measurement of serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.89 concentration in female dogs0.9 and cats0.96 before and after ovariohysterectomy. Anti-Mllerian hormone0.99 (AMH0.99), or Mllerian inhibitory substance0.99, is a hormone that is best known for its production by fetal testes in mammals and as the inhibitor of Mllerian (paramesonephric) duct development in males. However, following the development of the Mllerian ducts into the oviduct, uterus, and upper vagina in female mammals, the ovaries produce AMH0.97, which can be found in measureable amounts within the peripheral circulation, especially in adults. The ovaries appear to be the sole source of AMH0.99 in the circulation; therefore, it may be a useful marker in clinically relevant situations when an assessment of the presence or absence of ovaries or ovarian remnants in dogs0.97 and cats0.96 is important. To that end, a commercially available, human0.99-based assay was evaluated for the measurement of AMH0.99 in dogs0.95 and cats0.95. A preliminary assessment involved a single test on a set of serum0.51 samples from dogs0.91 that were submitted to a diagnostic endocrinology laboratory for other tests. Favorable preliminary results led to a more formal assessment of the assay using serum samples from dogs0.96 and cats0.94 with the presence or absence of the ovaries known by surgical confirmation. Overall, a single measurement of serum AMH0.89 concentration was highly effective at distinguishing ovariohysterectomized1.0 from intact adult animals. In addition, the assay also accurately identified several cases of ovarian remnant syndrome1.0

data.tiab: Follicle Stimulating Hormone Receptor1.0 (FSHR1.0) Polymorphisms and Polycystic Ovary Syndrome1.0 (PCOS1.0). Polycystic ovary syndrome1.0 (PCOS1.0) is the commonest endocrine abnormality1.0 in women0.88 of reproductive age typically presenting with chronic oligo- or anovulation0.96, clinical, or biochemical hyperandrogenism1.0 and polycystic ovarian morphology1.0 (PCOM1.0). Restoring mono-ovulation is the ultimate goal of ovulation induction and most women0.91 do respond to ovulation inducing agents causing their Follicle-stimulating hormone1.0 (FSH1.0) levels to rise. Familial clustering and the results from twin studies strongly support an underlying genetic basis for PCOS1.0. Recent Genome wide association studies (GWAS) have identified several genetic variants0.56 being genome wide significantly associated with PCOS1.0. Amongst those are variants in or near the Luteinizing hormone (LH) and FSH receptor genes0.93Luteinizing hormone1.0 (LH0.99) and FSH receptor genes0.95 as well as a variant in the FSH- gene1.0. The aim of this review is to summarize the available evidence as to whether single nucleotide polymorphisms0.92 are able to modify the PCOS0.99 phenotype or whether they constitute a risk factor for the syndrome. Data on the role of FSHR0.99 polymorphisms in PCOS1.0 are conflicting. It seems that in large Chinese studies FSHR1.0 polymorphisms are not associated with either PCOS1.0 risk or with PCOS1.0 treatment outcome. However, in large scale studies in Caucasians these polymorphisms0.76 seem to influence the risk of having PCOS1.0. Moreover, these studies also showed that some polymorphisms0.59 might affect some clinical features of PCOS0.94 as well as treatment outcome. Although most research has focussed on the role of FSHR1.0 polymorphisms there seems to be also some evidence showing that single nucleotide polymorphisms0.53 (SNPs) in the LHCG0.6LHCG-1.0Receptor as well as those in FSH- gene0.99 might also alter the phenotype of PCOS1.0. In conclusion most studies confirm that FSHR0.99 polymorphisms do alter the phenotype of PCOS1.0 in that they either alter the response to exogenous FSH0.93 or hat they increase the risk of having PCOS1.0

data.tiab: Opportunistic salpingectomy in women0.92 undergoing hysterectomy: Results from the HYSTUB randomised controlled trial. OBJECTIVE To evaluate whether opportunistic salpingectomy in premenopausal women0.94 undergoing hysterectomy for benign indications is both hormonally and surgically safe, compared with hysterectomy without salpingectomy. STUDY DESIGN In this multicentre randomised controlled trial, women0.93 were randomised to undergo either hysterectomy with opportunistic bilateral salpingectomy (intervention group) or standard hysterectomy with preservation of the Fallopian tubes (control group). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was the difference in serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.83 concentration (AMH0.98), measured pre-surgery and 6 months post-surgery. Secondary outcomes were surgical outcomes and duration of hospital stay. The sample size was powered at 50 participants0.97 per group (n=100) to compare AMH0.92 after hysterectomy with salpingectomy to AMH0.84 after standard hysterectomy. RESULTS Between March 2013 and December 2016, 104 women0.95, aged 30-55 years, were randomly allocated to hysterectomy with opportunistic bilateral salpingectomy (n=52) or standard hysterectomy (n=52). The baseline characteristics did not differ between the two groups. The median AMH0.95 was -0.14pmol/L (IQR -1.47-0.95) in the intervention group and 0.00pmol/L (IQR -1.05-0.80) in the control group (p=0.49). The addition of salpingectomy did not impair surgical results and it did not affect duration of hospital stay. CONCLUSION Addition of opportunistic bilateral salpingectomy during hysterectomy did not result in a larger effect on ovarian reserve when compared with hysterectomy alone, neither did it affect surgical outcomes. Therefore, opportunistic salpingectomy seems to be a safe procedure in premenopausal women0.92 undergoing hysterectomy for benign gynaecological conditions0.98

OBJECTIVE This study was performed to assess serum AMH0.78 levels in oligomenorrheic1.0 (OLIGO0.81) girls0.79 without evidence of hyperandrogenism1.0. DESIGN This was a prospective study comparing AMH0.98 levels in OLIGO1.0, PCOS1.0, and normal control adolescents. SETTING The study was conducted through four tertiary academic medical centers. PARTICIPANTS0.76 The study groups were comprised of OLIGO1.0 (n = 24), PCOS1.0 (n = 153), and normal adolescent0.49 girls0.76 (n = 39), as well as PCOS1.0 (n = 73) and normal adult women0.88 (n = 36). INTERVENTIONS In each subject, serum AMH0.96 levels were assessed in the early to midfollicular phases for regularly menstruating subjects and on an arbitrary day for OLIGO or PCOS1.0 subjects. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE(S) Basal serum AMH0.93 levels were assessed among OLIGO, PCOS1.0, and normal girls0.78, in addition to PCOS1.0 and normal women0.96. RESULTS OLIGO girls0.49 had serum AMH0.92 levels (5.33 +/- 0.47 ng/ml) that were significantly greater than the normal adolescents (3.05 +/- 0.31 ng/ml) and adults (2.33 +/- 0.22 ng/ml), but similar to values seen in the PCOS1.0 adolescents0.62 (5.28 +/- 0.26 ng/ml) and adults (6.36 +/- 0.47 ng/ml). Obese1.0 adolescents and PCOS1.0 women0.97 had significantly lower AMH0.99 levels compared to lean controls (P < 0.02). CONCLUSION In OLIGO1.0 adolescents, elevated serum AMH0.96 levels suggest increased antral follicle0.63 number similar to that observed in girls0.79 with PCOS1.0

data.tiab: Causal mechanisms and balancing selection inferred from genetic associations with polycystic ovary syndrome1.0. Polycystic ovary syndrome1.0 (PCOS1.0) is the most common reproductive disorder1.0 in women0.96, yet there is little consensus regarding its aetiology. Here we perform a genome-wide association study of PCOS1.0 in up to 5,184 self-reported cases of White European ancestry and 82,759 controls, with follow-up in a further 2,000 clinically validated cases and 100,000 controls. We identify six signals for PCOS0.99 at genome-wide statistical significance (P<5 10(-8)), in/near genes ERBB41.0/0.83HER41.0, YAP11.0, THADA0.99, FSHB0.99, RAD501.0 and KRR10.99. Variants in/near three of the four epidermal growth factor receptor genes1.0 (ERBB21.0/HER21.0, ERBB31.0/HER31.0 and ERBB41.0/HER41.0) are associated with PCOS0.99 at or near genome-wide significance. Mendelian randomization analyses indicate causal roles in PCOS1.0 aetiology for higher BMI (P=2.5 10(-9)), higher insulin1.0 resistance (P=6 10(-4)) and lower serum0.52 sex hormone binding globulin0.91 concentrations (P=5 10(-4)). Furthermore, genetic susceptibility to later menopause is associated with higher PCOS1.0 risk (P=1.6 10(-8)) and PCOS-susceptibility alleles0.44 are associated with higher serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.94 concentrations in girls0.86 (P=8.9 10(-5)). This large-scale study implicates an aetiological role of the epidermal growth factor receptors1.0, infers causal mechanisms relevant to clinical management and prevention, and suggests balancing selection mechanisms involved in PCOS1.0

data.tiab: [Anti-mullerian hormone1.0 in young women0.9 after chemotherapy and infradiaphragmatic radiotherapy for childhood cancer1.0]. INTRODUCTION Composed anticancer0.59 treatment leads to different late effects, such as ovarian failure1.0, causing infertility1.0 or premature menopause0.95. AIM OF THE STUDY was to analyse ovarian function, particularly anti-mullerian hormone1.0 levels, in young females after anticancer treatment. PATIENTS0.97 AND METHODS We analysed FSH1.0, LHnan, estradiol1.0 and anti-mullerian hormone1.0 (AMH0.99) levels on days 3-5 of a menstrual cycle in thirty three cancer1.0 survivors in mean age 19.1+/-4.7 years treated in age 12.0+/-5.6 years for Hodgkin Lymphoma1.0 (HL1.0) (n=16), nephroblastoma1.0 (n=7), soft tissue sarcoma1.0 (n=4), germinal tumor1.0 (n=3), neuroblastoma1.0 (n=2), histiocytosis1.0 (n=1). Infradiaphragmatic radiotherapy was needed in 16 patients0.98 (10 treated for HLnan). Results were compared with healthy girls0.82 of the same age. RESULTS The mean values of FSH1.0, LHnan, E2 and AMH0.98 did not differ in all survivors comparing to controls. Patients0.97 treated for HLnan with chemo- and radiotherapy presented higher FSH1.0 levels than controls (8.53+/-3.25 vs. 5.8+/-2.03 mIU/ml; p=0.045). Mean AMH0.99 levels were lower in all patients0.99 that received radiotherapy for the infradiaphragmatic region (17.19+/-14.84 pmol/l) than in controls (29.40+/-13.2 pmol/l; p=0.037). Particular analysis of all cases showed higher (>2 SD) FSH1.0 levels in 8 patients0.99: 5 patients0.99 treated for HLnan with radiotherapy and higher total doses of procarbazine1.0, nitrogen mustard1.0 and vinblastine1.0; 2 patients0.99 treated for soft tissue sarcoma1.0 and one patient0.95 for Wilms tumor1.0 (all received radiotherapy). Lowered AMH0.98 levels were found in 8 patients0.99 treated with chemo- and radiotherapy (4 - for HLnan, 2 - for Wilms tumor1.0 and 2 - for soft tissue sarcoma0.99). CONCLUSION Composed anticancer treatment, especially radiotherapy, leads to ovarian failure1.0. Decreased AMH0.99 values at young adulthood suggest a lower ovarian reserve. All causes and first symptoms of ovary damage should be known to the doctors who take care of the patients0.99

data.tiab: Decline in ovarian reserve may be an undiagnosed reason for unexplained infertility1.0: a cohort study. Introduction Unexplained infertility1.0 refers to the absence of a definable cause for a couple's failure to achieve pregnancy. Reproductive aging plays a role in pathogenesis of unexplained infertility1.0. We investigated the results of ovarian reserve tests in unexplained infertility0.97. Material and methods The patients0.99 were divided into two groups: unexplained infertility0.81 (n = 148) and male factor infertility1.0 (n = 112). Follicle-stimulating hormone1.0, estradiol1.0, inhibin b0.99 levels and anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 levels were evaluated. Antral follicle count and ovarian volume measurements were performed. Results The demographic variables were comparable. Follicle-stimulating hormone0.99 levels were higher in the unexplained infertility group than the male factor infertility1.0 group, although this difference did not reach statistical significance (p = 0.071). Estradiol1.0 levels, inhibin b0.99 concentrations and ovarian volume showed no difference between groups. However, antral follicle0.55 count was significantly lower in the unexplained infertility group than the male factor infertility0.99 group (p = 0.023). The median anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 concentrations were significantly lower in the unexplained infertility group 1.42 (0.4-6.2) than in the male factor infertility0.99 group (2.04 (0.64-8.2); p = 0.001). Conclusions Although anti-Mllerian hormone values and antral follicle0.61 count were higher than the low thresholds, a statistically significant decline of ovarian reserve in the unexplained infertility0.75 group was found in the present study. This might be an undiagnosed reason for unexplained infertility1.0

data.tiab: Effects of Dietary Contamination by Zearalenone1.0 and Its Metabolites on Serum Anti-Mllerian Hormone0.95: Impact on the Reproductive Performance of Breeding Cows0.64. We investigated the effects of in vivo exposure to low zearalenone1.0 levels on the anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 endocrine levels and the reproductive performance of cattle0.92. Urinary zearalenone1.0, -zearalenol0.99 and -zearalenol0.96 concentrations were measured by chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry, and serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.97 concentrations were determined along with serum biochemical parameters. Urinary concentrations of -zearalenol0.9 were significantly higher (p < 0.05) in cattle0.97 in Herd 1 than in cattle0.97 in Herd 2, reflecting the different amounts of zearalenone1.0 in the diet of the two herds. Although the number of 5-mm and 10-mm follicles of the herds and their fertility after artificial insemination were similar, the serum anti-Mllerian hormone0.89 concentrations in herds0.46 1 and 2 were 438.9 48.6 pg/ml and 618.9 80.0 pg/ml, respectively, with a trend towards a significant difference (p = 0.053), which may indicate differences in the antral follicle populations0.69 between herds. Thus, zearalenone1.0 intake from dietary feed, even when below the threshold zearalenone1.0 contamination level permitted in Japan, may affect the ovarian antral follicle populations0.72, but not the fertility, of post-partum cows0.98

data.tiab: The Trends and Hotspots in Premature Ovarian Insufficiency1.0 Therapy from 2000 to This study aims to map the knowledge structure and themes trends of primary ovarian insufficiency1.0 (POI1.0) therapy to help researchers rapidly master the hotspots and prospects of POI0.96 therapy from the increasing number of publications. The literature search and bibliometric analyses were performed by using Web of Science Core Collection and VOSviewer. Annual publications from 2000 to 2022 continued to increase with some fluctuations. The most productive country, organization, and journal were the USA, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, and Human0.78 Reproduction, respectively. Harvard University was the organization with the highest citation. Fertility and Sterility0.94 and Nelson, L.M. were the most influential journal and author, respectively. Seven clusters separated by keywords association showed the extensive scope of POI therapy. The hotspots of POI1.0 therapy were hormone replacement therapy and fertility preservation, and the innovative treatment strategies including in vitro activation and mesenchymal0.71mesenchymal stem cells0.83

data.tiab: Anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 and lifestyle, reproductive, and environmental factors among women0.95 in rural South Africa. BACKGROUND Few data exist regarding anti-Mllerian hormone1.0, a marker of ovarian reserve, in relation to environmental factors with potential ovarian toxicity. METHODS This analysis included 420 women0.96 from Limpopo, South Africa studied in 2010-2011. Women0.92 were administered comprehensive questionnaires, and plasma concentrations of anti-Mllerian hormone0.99 and dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane1.0 were determined. We used separate multivariable models to examine the associations between natural log-transformed anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 concentration (ng/ml) and each of the lifestyle, reproductive, and environmental factors of interest, adjusted for age, body mass index, education, and parity. RESULTS The median age of women0.91 was 24 years (interquartile range [IQR] = 22 to 26); the median anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 concentration was 3.1 ng/ml (IQR = 2.0 to 6.0). Women0.95 who reported indoor residual spraying in homes with painted walls (indicative of exposure to pyrethroids1.0) had 25% lower (95% confidence interval [CI] = -39%, -8%) anti-Mllerian hormone0.99 concentrations compared with women0.95 who reported no spraying. Little evidence of decreased anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 concentrations was observed among women0.92 with the highest dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane1.0 levels. Compared with women0.98 who used an electric stove, no association was observed among women0.97 who cooked indoors over open wood fires. The findings also suggested lower anti-Mllerian hormone0.99 concentrations among women0.94 who drank coffee (-19% [95% CI = -31%, -5%]) or alcohol1.0 (-21% [95% CI = -36%, -3%]). CONCLUSIONS These are among the first data regarding anti-Mllerian hormone1.0 concentrations relative to pesticides and indoor air pollution. Our results are suggestive of decreased ovarian reserve associated with exposure to pyrethroid1.0
